existence. "And God breathed into his nostrils
the breath of life, and man became a living
soul." One is ever doubting the revelation
God has made of himself. "Can these
things be." is the habitual language of his
heart, and as he will not seek instruction
from the one infallible teacher, he fails to
answer the question with any satisfaction
to himself.
But, while we are thus talking, our
friends have returned from their walk
and the iron horse, with snorts and puffs,
has started them once more upon their
journey. Let us not disturb them in their

Travels, but look in upon them after they have
Salted for the night. They take lodgings in the
same hotel, and their rooms open into the same
hall. For awhile they both rest calmly, but hark,
near midnight there are sounds which bespeak
a coming storm. After a few warning rumblings,
the thunder breaks forth with such terrific
force that it startles all the inmates of the
city. Slumber is forgotten, and trembling seizes
many a heart. 
Crash follows crash in quick succession. One
brilliant, earthward flash and bursting peal
tell that the lightening has struck not far
away. No marvel so many hearts quake with
fear, but how is it with our friends? Each
awakes with a start, but with returning consciousness
there comes to the christian man a
recognition of his father's voice, and fear
gives place to adoration. The unbeliever also
with sudden conviction now cries out, "O God, 
how terrible!" There seems to be a 
glimpse of truth, revealed by this sudden
danger, and as another fearful crash is heard,

with pale lips he exclaims, "save me, O, my God!"
Too often does our own experience accord
with this. When life is calm and peaceful, how
inclined we are to harbor unjust doubts of God's
power and love, but when sudden danger assails
us, involuntarily we acknowledge him,
and passionately cry to him for help.
Selfish as this may be, does it not teach
a lesson we would do well to heed?
What is it that thus leads the heart from all false
trust, and turns its cry to the only one who can
help? May it not be something implanted in
our being by our kind Creator, akin to the
instinct with which he has armed his dumb
creatures? And if so, is it not a safer guide than
our prejudiced, misguided reason, which so
often fails us when most needed? Instinct
never errs; its lessons, though limited, are always
perfect, and does not this involuntary stretching
of the hands to God when danger is imminent,
seem like an instinctive cry in the right direction,
which we can with safety repeat
in our calmer moments?

When God gave man a mind,
he presented him with the grandest gift
at the divine disposal. Think, for a moment,
what it has achieved. The wonderful inventions
of the present and the past ages, all had their
birth place in the human mind. The successful
coworking of different inventions and various
agencies, bringing to perfection what seemed
a dream in its first conception, show what
the thinking brain can do. Two countries,
held asunder not only by a thousand miles,
but by a thousand leagues of defiant waves,
with perfect composure and almost noiseless
voice holding converse! Think of this, and tell
one, is not the mind a God like gift?
Yet, brothers, sisters, almost with trembling
do we speak it, it is a gift bestowed upon
each one of us, a gift that will exist as long
as God himself! And shall we use it lightly?
We condemn the man in the parable,

who hid his Lord's money, but what was one
talent of money, compared with the many
and varied talents of mind, each capable of
an almost limitless growth, with which our
Master has entrusted us? We may be tempted
to say, it is not much that our little minds
can accomplish, but, is there such a thing
as a little mind? A mind may be dwarfed
in growth, and cramped in action, but in
its elements, in its possibilities, is not every
mind great? Henry Ward Beecher, says,
"I honor every man for the possibility of
good there is in him, so ought we to respect
every mind, our own among the number
for the possibilities of good there are in them.
I have no doubt than any one present,
who should studiously and perseveringly
cultivate his powers of thought, would, in
a few years, have his name placed in the
honored list of great men. But idle waiting
will not bring success. Think you that that
eloquent speaker gained such a ready flow

of thrilling words without culture, or that
that successful lawyer attained his present
power through listless inaction? But O, limit
not your powers till you have tried them,
for remember, they are not powers of your
own creating, but are the workmanship of
the Infinite!
It is not inventive genius, nor thrilling
eloquence alone that is useful; our common,
every, day thoughts are not without their
worth, and may be made a ministration
of good, if we will only so employ them.
As man is social, mutually dependent
upon his brother man, it is little better than
robbery to keep our thoughts buried within
our own bosoms. The Giver of all good, to
guard our selfish natures from such monopoly,
gives this warning, "But to do good, and
to communicate, forget not," and do we 
not as truly heed the warning when we

communicate a pure, fresh thought, as
when we impart some of our worldly
goods? In this land of plenty, a hungry
soul is oftener met than a hungry body.
I have one, you have one, and we should
feed one another. Nor need we fear that
such generosity will impoverish us.
The mind is not like any other store house;
the more frequent the draft upon its resources,
the fuller will be its larders. Of this, most
appropriately it may he said, "There is that
scattereth, and yet increaseth."
Might we not save some useful thoughts,
which owing to our neglect, come to us often as
only strugglings after a new idea, half glimpses
of something we do not even give a name, if
we were to keep a pencil and strip of paper
near at hand, and when we have such
glimpses, ask ourselves what we see, pause a
moment till the picture grows more clear,
then paint it in simple words to be reproduced
at need? Some such habit as this would give

us something to glean from when a sudden
demand was made upon our resources, and
might perhaps save us from being so
startled when requested to write an essay,
or to furnish an article for the paper.
Say not that the thoughts which flit through
your minds are unworthy of notice.
Analyze them and see. Follow them in
their leadings, and you will be astonished
to find how much there is in them.
For our quiet hours, how often does nature
try to speak to us, and her lessons grow ten
fold more frequent, and a hundred fold
more clear as we learn to listen. Let us
try to find what some of these whisperings
mean. Perchance we may hear an illustration 
of a truth too little heeded, or
an assurance of a promise too readily
doubted, or a breathing of the All Father's
wondrous love, in either case, something
too precious to be slighted. Who will say,
that in some earnest communing with

nature, a grand truth, before unknown
to us, may not be revealed, as the law of
gravitation was revealed to Newton, while he
watched that apple fall to the ground?
Dear brothers and sisters, bound
together as we are by the shining links
of Faith, Hope and Charity shall we
not to night form a closer alliance, by
a united consecration of our thoughts to the
service of the pure, the good, and the true?
Yes, a consecration, then we shall
have no right, no wish to withhold them
when demanded by a cause so pure,
so good, so true as temperance.
Let us not be hindered by a false fear
that a moderate confidence in our own
powers will faster a spirit of egotism,
and furnish food for pride. Of what,
pray, shall we be proud, for what have we
that we have not received? but with ever
greatful remembrance of Him who
furnishes the spring of all our thoughts,

may we not, with humble earnestness,
use these precious gifts of his, "as not
abusing them?"
Remsen, July 8, 1869.

great exertion of mind is required. Men that have become
distinquished in the world have not become so without great
study: they have not been at ease and expected knowledge
to come into their heads. They have been ambitious to learn

But we must not be contented with learning studying

must learn to think for himself.
